studies.title: Clostridium butyricum-induced ω-3 fatty acid 18-HEPE elicits anti-influenza virus pneumonia effects through interferon-λ upregulation
studies.description: The precise mechanism by which butyrate-producing bacteria in the gut contribute to resistance to respiratory viral infections remains to be elucidated. Here, we describe a gut-lung axis mechanism and report that orally administered Clostridium butyricum (CB) enhances influenza virus infection resistance through upregulation of interferon (IFN)-λ in lung epithelial cells. Gut microbiome-induced ω-3 fatty acid 18-hydroxy eicosapentaenoic acid (18-HEPE) promotes IFN-λ production through the G protein-coupled receptor (GPR)120 and IFN regulatory factor (IRF)-1/-7 activations. CB promotes 18-HEPE production in the gut and enhances ω-3 fatty acid sensitivity in the lungs by promoting GPR120 expression. This study finds a gut-lung axis mechanism and provides insights into the treatments and prophylaxis for viral respiratory infections.

publications.title: Clostridium butyricum-induced ω-3 fatty acid 18-HEPE elicits anti-influenza virus pneumonia effects through interferon-λ upregulation
publications.authorList: Hagihara M, Yamashita M, Ariyoshi T, Eguchi S, Minemura A, Miura D, Higashi S, Oka K, Nonogaki T, Mori T, Iwasaki K, Hirai J, Shibata Y, Umemura T, Kato H, Asai N, Yamagishi Y, Ota A, Takahashi M, Mikamo H

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description: Briefly, 8-week old Balb/c mice were divided into 3 groups: (I) Mock group (n = 4), (II) influenza virus infection group (n = 10) and (III) influenza virus infection and CBM 588 administration group (n = 10). Samples were then stored at -80 °C until extraction. The colon and lungs were lyophilized and 10 mg was weighed after ball milling process.

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description: Lyophilized colon and lung samples (10 mg) were added to a solution consisting of 500 μL of methanol, and the resulting mixture was vigorously vortexed for 1 min. The mixture was then centrifuged at 15,000 rpm for 3 min, and the supernatant was collected. The supernatant was dried under reduced pressure, followed by addition of 50 µL of acetonitrile and vortexing for 1 min. Alternatively, 180 µL methanol was added to 20 µL of blood samples, and the mixture was vortexed for 1 min. The mixture was then centrifuged at 15,000 x g for 3 min, and the supernatant was collected into 300 μL vial.

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description: Vanquish H system (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cleveland, OH, USA) using an Acclaim RSLC120 C18 (2.2 µm 2.1 i.d. × 150 mm, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cleveland, OH, USA). Mobile phase A was prepared using MilliQ containing 0.1% formic acid and mobile phase B was acetonitrile. After equilibration with 20% mobile phase solution B, 2 µL of the sample was injected and measured. The flow condition of the LC was eluted at a flow rate of 0.4 mL/min. Linear gradient condition: 0.0 min 80% A, 0.5 min 80% A, 15.0 min 2% A, 25.0 min 2% A, 25.0 min 80% A, 32.0 min 80% A.

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description: The orbitrap LC-MS/MS analyses were performed on a Q Exactive (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Cleveland, OH, USA). The source was an ESI operated in negative mode. Settings were as follows; Spray voltage 3 kV, Vaporizer temperature 350 °C, Capillary temperature 275 °C, Sheath N2 gas flow rate 50 psi, Aux N2 gas flow rate 15 psi, S-lens level 50 and Probe position C +1.75. Full MS resolution was 7.00 e^4 with scan range 215-800 m/z, AGC target 1.00 e^6 and maximum IT 100 ms. Data-dependent acquisition (DDA) MS/MS resolution was 1.75 e^4, Isolation window (m/z) ±0.8 Da, Stepped normalized collision energy 20/40/60, Loop count 3, AGC target 5.00 e^4, Maximum IT 60 ms, Dynamic exclusion 4/10/30 s and Intensity threshold 8.00 e^4.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description: The raw files were produced by Xcalibur Version 4.1, using the software Compound Discoverer Version 3.1, and the negative ion mode data were imported into Compound Discoverer Version 3.1 software for data preprocessing, filtering, alignment and peak identification.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description: The identified metabolites, retention times (Rt), mass-to-charge ratios (m/z), peak area values, MS and MS/MS fragments, and pathway information were obtained for all samples. The raw files were normalized by Compound Discoverer Version 3.1 software and MS and MS/MS fragments were used to compare the MS fragment and MS/MS fragment library mzCloud and MS fragment library ChemSpider.

assays.technologyPlatform: Liquid Chromatography MS - negative - reverse phase
